title: What is the enthalpy of neutralisation of 0.2 mol H+ (aq) with 0.1 mol OH-(aq)? - Quora

response.answer_text: So we have 0.1 mole OH- and 0.2 mole of H+ So 0.1 mole H+ reacts with 0.1 mole OH- leaving behind 0.1 mole H+. Thus, the change in enthalpy is equal to the enthalpy of neutralization of 0.1 mole H+ with 0.1 mole OH-. Thus, the enthalpy change associated is -5.762 kJ at 25 °C or 5.762 kJ of heat is released(since enthalpy change for neutralization 1 mole of H+ with 1 mole of OH- is -57.62 kJ/mol at 25 °C, that is, the reaction is exothermic).
